awd_titl_txt: Effects of Background Wind on the Eastward Propagation of Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO) is referred to organized large-scale tropical convection system that slowly propagate eastward with an average time scale of 40-60 days around the equator. As they do so, they influence global weather patterns. One of the questions that remains to be understood fully is why some of these events move faster or slower than others. This project aims to explain part of the variability in the eastward propagating speed of MJO by linking it to slowly evolving background winds. Through analysis of observed and model data, this project will identify how these background winds alter the movements of the regions of tropical rainfall and the associated global weather patterns. A unique combination of statistics and the background momentum budget analyses will help to isolate the roles of tropical intrusion of extratropical disturbances in regulating the background wind system and thereby inter-event variations of eastward propagating speeds of MJO.

Weather models do not predict well how these tropical rainfall patterns evolve. The improved understanding of how MJO interacts with the global weather would help improve weather forecasting in the important period for decision, 2-5 weeks into the future. Better understanding how these background wind patterns influence MJO's propagation also help identify error sources of existing numerical weather prediction models. Graduate students will be trained to perform research activities and will present papers at conferences and submit results for peer review.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO) is a pattern of alternating wet and dry weather and associated winds that progresses eastward across the global tropics at a few meters per second, and that affects weather outcomes worldwide. This project assessed differences between slow and fast MJO events, and studied how seasonally evolving background wind patterns in the upper troposphere affect how quickly it propagates. Results show that the slowest MJO events over the Indian Ocean experience the strongest upper tropospheric easterly wind. That is, MJO events advance eastward most slowly when they encounter the strongest upper tropospheric head winds. The results also show that after adjusting the propagation speed to account for the effect of the wind, the slowest events are also the wettest ones. These events occur at phase speeds of between 4 and 5 meters per second without adjusting them for background wind. Thus results also suggest that moist processes result in a slower MJO. 

Finally, results show that slow and fast events tend to be associated with different weather patterns around the world as they progress eastward. These different weather patterns result partly from the tropical MJO events moving at different speeds relative to the atmospheric waves they force into the middle latitudes. Further differences emerge from differences in the structures between slow and fast events and the background weather conditions that favor slow or fast events. 

Results suggest that the upper tropospheric wind pattern of the MJO is dominated by a disturbance known as a Kelvin wave. Wave dynamics likely dominate the phenomenon, but moisture, including thunderstorm activity, provides it an energy source. 

Understanding the factors that control phase speed of the MJO may help us improve weather prediction models and to predict the most likely global weather outcomes when MJO events happen to move more slowly or more quickly than average.
